Experience: Director of the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing

I report to the Chairperson of the Department of Microbiology and Immunology. I participate in team-teaching of immunology within the Biomedical Sciences Graduate Program. I also lead educational activities, especially those involving community outreach and education as to the activities and achievements of the ImmunoX community. I devise and help to implement an educational program, through CoLabs and ImmunoX, for postdoctoral and clinical research fellows to do 1+ year embedded periods of study in the CoLabs for the purposes of learning clinical-translational pipelines and career development.

I am in charge of the overall operations of the ImmunoX program (http://ImmunoX.ucsf.edu/), from the day-to-day to the big picture problems. I report directly to the Chairperson and sit on the ImmunoX Leadership Committee with the primary responsibility of advising and implementing decisions. I oversee and professionalize the Immunology Program at UCSF, and also focus on launching forward-thinking ImmunoX CoProjects within the UCSF CoLabs. As lead scientist, I also drive specific projects towards publications, including playing a significant authorship role in a selection of projects. I interface with faculty, strategic alliance, and donors, industry, and government funding agencies to see new science forward. On a secondary level, I am responsible for developing inclusive inward-facing initiatives, such as the Early Career Support for Women Program and the Technician Professional Development Program, as well as outward-facing initiatives such as outreach and an evolving social media presence for the public.

I co-direct a ~$14M+ UCSF-industry consortium (http://www.immunoprofiler.org/) with Bristol-Myers Squibb, Amgen, AbbVie, and Pfizer that seeks to find classes of patients based on deep profiling of tumor immune microenvironments of 14+ human cancers. To date, the consortium has profiled 500+ cases of primary and metastatic tumors and banked matching blood using multiparameter flow cytometry (~85-colors), transcriptomic analysis of immune cells, genomic analysis of tumor cells, and multiplexed immunofluorescence imaging. I manage a project team that includes technicians, postdoctoral and clinical fellows, bioinformaticians, and pathologist, surgeons, and oncologists. Finally, I oversee a clinical-translational database that houses all aforementioned data types, including clinical data, that is being mined to ultimately determine how to treat cancers and provide new targets for the next round of immunotherapies.

Experience: Professor of Biological Engineering and Computer Science

Our research is focused on the analysis of complex biological systems at both the molecular level and the systems level. Our molecular work concentrates on the structure and properties of proteins, nucleic acids, and their complexes. Investigations probe the sources of stability and specificity that drive folding and binding events of macromolecules. Studies are aimed at dissecting the interactions responsible for the specific structure of folded proteins and the binding geometry of molecular complexes. The roles played by salt bridges, hydrogen bonds, side-chain packing, rotameric states, solvation, and the hydrophobic effect in native biomolecules are being explored, and strategies for re-casting these roles through structure-based molecular design are being developed.

Our work at the systems level involves the construction and analysis of correlated patterns of gene expression and their relation to biochemical regulatory networks and signal transduction pathways in cells. Much of this work is motivated by the enormous advances in genome science and in the availability of parallel arrays of gene expression data. The methods of theoretical and computational biophysics and approaches from artificial intelligence, applied mathematics, and chemical engineering play key roles in our work

I founded the Signal Kinetics research group in the MIT Media Lab and the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science. My research group invents, builds, and deploys wireless and sensor technology in order to address complex problems in society, industry, and ecology. My research received prestigious early-career honors including the National Science Foundation CAREER Award (2019), the Office of Naval Research Young Investigator Award (2019), and the Google Faculty Research Award (2017). My team also received the ACM SIGCOMM Best Paper Award (2019) and the Ocean Observing Explorer Prize from the US Department of Energy and NOAA (2020).
Education: My Ph.D. thesis laid the theoretical and practical foundations for wireless/WiFi sensing, and it received the ACM SIGMOBILE Dissertation Award in 2018, recognizing it as the world's best dissertation in wireless networks and mobile computing. This research was also named as one of the 50 ways MIT has transformed Computer Science, and I was invited to demo it to President Obama at the White House (2015). Because of this work, I was named as one of the world's top 35 under 35 by Technology Review and to Forbes' list of 30 under 30. Commercialized technologies based on my research are being used by major hospitals and pharmaceutical companies to monitor patients with Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Epilepsy, and COVID-19.
My Master's thesis, "See Through Walls with WiFi!", received the best masters thesis award in computer science at MIT.
Graduated with the highest GPA on the university's record

Lead the Energy-Efficient Multimedia Systems Group

The Energy-Efficient Multimedia Systems Group aims to develop and implement energy-efficient and high-performance systems for multimedia applications such as machine learning, computer vision, video compression and imaging. We focus on the joint design of algorithms, architectures, circuits and systems to enable optimal tradeoffs between power, speed, and quality of result. Accordingly, our work traverses various levels of abstraction from energy-aware algorithm development for signal processing to efficient architecture design and low-power VLSI circuit implementation.
* Energy-Efficient Computer Vision, Machine Learning and Autonomous Navigation

Experience: We aim to develop micro-scale robotic systems that can demonstrate insect-like locomotive capabilities in aerial, aquatic, and terrestrial environments. To design highly agile, multifunctional, and robust micro-scale robots, we work on (1) develop high bandwidth and robust soft actuators and active materials for locomotion and manipulation, (2) investigate and apply physical phenomena (surface tension, fluid-structure interaction, friction, electrostatics) at the millimeter scale in designing multifunctional robots, and (3) develop design and fabrication tools suitable for rapid prototyping of hybrid soft-rigid robots. We envision our work will find applications such as inspection, surgical robots, and environmental monitoring.
- Developed a 1.6 g, hybrid terrestrial-aquatic microrobot that can walk on land, water surface, and underwater
- Apply fluid mechanical phenomena at the millimeter scale (electrowetting, capillary action) in microrobotic systems

Experience: Emerald is an MIT spin-off for non-invasive health monitoring. Our team has developed the world's first Wi-Fi like box that analyzes the surrounding radio signals using neural networks, and infers people's movements, breathing, heart rate, falls, sleep apnea, and sleep stages -- all in a touchless manner without requiring users to wear any sensors. Emerald provides continuous health data and predictive analyses to doctors, researchers, and pharmaceutical and insurance companies. To see a live demo of the Emerald technology check Professor Katabi's TED talk (To see Emerald in action, check out Prof. Katabi's TED talk ( https://www.ted.com/talks/dina_katabi_a_new_way_to_monitor_vital_signs_that_can_see_through_walls?language=en) or  our White House demo (https://youtu.be/aKsxHS5vptM?t=650 )

Dina Katabi is the Andrew & Erna Viterbi Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at MIT. She is also the director of the MIT’s Center for Wireless Networks and Mobile Computing, a member of the National Academy of Engineering, and a recipient of the MacArthur Genius Award.  Professor Katabi received her PhD and MS from MIT in 2003 and 1999, and her Bachelor of Science from Damascus University in 1995.  Katabi's research focuses on innovations in mobile computing, wireless sensing, and machine learning with application to digital health.  Her research has been recognized with ACM Prize in Computing, the ACM Grace Murray Hopper Award, two SIGCOMM Test of Time Awards, the Faculty Research Innovation Fellowship, a Sloan Fellowship, the NBX Career Development chair, and the NSF CAREER award. Her students received the ACM Best Doctoral Dissertation Award in Computer Science and Engineering twice. Further, her work was recognized by the IEEE William R. Bennett prize, three ACM SIGCOMM Best Paper awards, an NSDI Best Paper award, and a TR10 award. Several start-ups have been spun out of Katabi's lab such as PiCharging and Emerald.

Along with Shafi Goldwasser, for work which laid the complexity-theoretic foundations for the science of cryptography, and in the process pioneered new methods for efficient verification of mathematical proofs in complexity theory.

Research and teaching in machine learning and artificial intelligence. Lead the Clinical Machine Learning Group (http://clinicalml.org), studying how machine learning can transform health care through more accurate and timely diagnosis and risk stratification, disease progression modeling, prediction of treatment effectiveness, and changing the way clinicians interact with patient data. Principal investigator in the Institute for Medical Engineering & Science (IMES) and the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), and faculty in the Harvard–MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST) program.

Faculty in the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences and the Center for Data Science. Taught computer science and data science at both undergraduate and graduate levels, and led research group that applies machine learning to health care. Received National Science Foundation CAREER Award in 2014.

Performed machine learning research with applications to personalizing web search (in collaboration with Bing) and early detection of sepsis (in collaboration with Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center). Published 4 articles and filed 2 patents.

Internships at Google during the summers of 2002, 2003, and 2007. In 2002, worked on Ads team. In 2003, worked on algorithms for detecting web spam. In 2007, worked on improving structure learning for Rephil, a probabilistic topic model widely used at Google.
Education: Ph.D. thesis on machine learning, advised by Professor Tommi Jaakkola. Developed a new approach for probabilistic inference in very large statistical models (Bayesian networks and Markov random fields) using linear programming relaxations. Recognition included the George M. Sprowls Award for the best doctoral thesis in Computer Science at MIT in 2010, best paper awards at EMNLP, UAI, and NeurIPS, a NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, and the Google Fellowship in Machine Learning.
Member of Phi Beta Kappa and Upsilon Pi Epsilon (Computer Science honors society). Studied abroad at Lund University in Sweden, Fall 2005. President of UPE in Spring 2005.

Awarded the EECS Department Citation for most outstanding senior in the department, 2005, and was a University Medal Finalist, one of the 6 most distinguished graduating seniors at UC Berkeley. Research in Artificial Intelligence with Professor Stuart Russell from 2003-05, helping develop the field of probabilistic programming.

Experience: Cambridge Mobile Telematics (CMT) develops innovative mobile sensing technology and data analytics to change driving behavior and make roads safer around the world. CMT's products are being used daily by customers worldwide in popular mobile applications, triggering significant changes in the global insurance market.

Founded by two MIT professors and experienced entrepreneurs (a spin-off from the CarTel research project), and located in Kendall Square in Cambridge, MA, CMT has attracted a strong team of computer scientists and business leaders. See http://www.cmtelematics.com for more information.

We are hiring people with expertise in mobile software/systems, web/backend/cloud infrastructure, and large-scale data analytics (machine learning / inference). Please email jobs@cmtelematics.com if you (or someone you know) would like to learn more about these opportunities.
MIT Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
Education: Columbia University in the City of New York

Experience: Cambridge Mobile Telematics (CMT) seeks to make the world's roads and drivers safer. It uses innovative mobile sensing, statistics, AI, and behavioral science to accurately measure driving quality, improve driving behavior, and help people in car crashes with real-time assistance. CMT's DriveWell program pioneered "behavior-based insurance" using smartphone telematics in 2012, and has added many enhancements since. In 2014, CMT invented the DriveWell Tag IoT device, the first low-power BLE-based sensor device to augment smartphone sensors for accurate measurements of both vehicular dynamics. As of 2020, CMT has shipped over 16 million Tags. CMT's Claims Studio provides crash detection for real-time assistance and AI-based crash reconstruction for better claims processing. CMT's products and solutions are now being used by several million users worldwide (25 countries as of mid-2020) in popular mobile applications, triggering significant changes in the global insurance market. CMT has received numerous awards and honors from TU-Automotive, Celent, TiE, and other organizations, and is today the world's largest and leading telematics service provider.

Founded based on pioneering research from MIT CSAIL, and located across the street from MIT in Cambridge, CMT has attracted a strong team of engineers, researchers, product, and business leaders in mobile sensing and IoT, AI, cloud infrastructure, data science, statistics, and insurtech. See http://www.cmtelematics.com for more information.

We are hiring for many roles, and are also always interested in anyone with the qualifications and desire to work on these problems! Please see https://www.cmtelematics.com/who-we-are/join-our-team/ to learn more.

Research and teaching in networked computer systems, including mobile & sensor computing, Internet architecture and protocols, wireless networks, data management, overlay/P2P networks, and network security. I co-founded and served as the Faculty Co-Director of Wireless@MIT, a Center for Wireless and Mobile Computing launched at MIT as a partnership between academia and industry. Teaching includes various courses on networks, IoT and mobile computing, and computer systems. Joined as Assistant Professor in 1998, received tenure as Associate Professor in 2003, promoted to Professor in 2006.

Advisor to Meraki from its pre-founding days. Meraki was a pioneer in delivering low-cost, reliable wireless mesh networks to the world. One of the technologies it developed was cloud-based network management for Wi-Fi networks, which helped it succeed with compelling products in the enterprise access point business as well.

Co-founded this spin-off that was based on academic research on data stream processing technologies.  StreamBase was the first commercial stream processing engine, a category now called "complex event processing".  The software enables users to rapidly build systems that analyze and act on real-time streaming data for rapid decision-making. StreamBase was subsequently acquired by TIBCO.

Developed new algorithms, technologies, and patents for Sandburst's network processing chipsets and switch fabric, focusing on traffic (switch) scheduling, routing table compression, and other such methods.  Sandburst was subsequently acquired by Broadcom.
Education: Distinguished Alumnus, UC Berkeley EECS Department, 2021

Thesis topic: TCP over heterogeneous wireless networks, including the TCP Snoop Protocol, algorithms for improving TCP performance over asymmetric & packet radio networks (ACK suppression and ACK reconstruction), and TCP improvements for small window connections (including a scheme called "enhanced recovery", which is now known as "limited transmit" and is implemented in most TCP stacks today. I also worked with collaborators on analyzing network data from the 1996 Atlanta Olympic Games web server, empirical analysis of the stability of network performance, and a comparison of log-structured and extent-based file systems. My work as a graduate student received best student paper awards at the MobiCom and USENIX conferences, and won the 1998 ACM doctoral dissertation award.

Experience: Professor of Information and Computer Science
Associate Professor of Electrical and Biomedical Engineering
W.M. Keck Career Development Professor in Biomedical Engineering
Assistant Professor of Electrical and Biomedical Engineering
Hermann von Helmholtz Career Development Professor
Leading the Integrative Neuromonitoring and Critical Care Informatics Group

•	Co-founder and co-director of the Computational Physiology & Clinical Inference Group at MIT’s Research Laboratory of Electronics. Principal Investigator directing the research and funding strategy for a ten-member research team at one of MIT’s largest interdisciplinary research laboratories.

•	Conduct research in systems-physiology, mathematical modeling of physiological systems, model identification, and biomedical signal processing, with applications to medical device development, to address critical needs in cardiovascular, respiratory, and neurological patient monitoring.

•	Co-inventor of patent-pending, award-winning technology for noninvasive, continuous, and patient-specific estimation of intracranial pressure, drawing licensing interest from medical device companies.

•	Build and manage close collaborative ties to teams of neonatologists, anesthesiologists, neurocritical care physicians, and neurosurgeons for clinical evaluation of novel patient monitoring modalities; courtesy appointments in neurology (Boston Children’s Hospital) and neonatology (Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center).
•	Communicate research results in top-tier scientific journals and as invited speaker at international workshops and conferences.
•	Teach quantitative physiology, cardiovascular and respiratory systems modeling in Europe, North and South America.
•	Designed and implemented electronic analysis system for real-time optical detection and discrimination of bio-aerosols.
•	Helped optimize optical sampling technique for real-time detection of bio-aerosols.
Education: Medical Engineering / Medical Physics, Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences & Technology
Member of the Laboratory for Computational Physiology at the Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences & Technology.
